revision.text:
{{Spanish name|Rico|González}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Sergio Rico | image = Sergio Rico.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Rico with [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] in 2017 | fullname = Sergio Rico González{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/844127|title=2018/19 Premier League squads confirmed|publisher=Premier League|date=3 September 2018|accessdate=4 September 2018}} | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1993|9|1|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Seville]], Spain | height = 1.94 m{{cite web|url=https://www.premierleague.com/players/7213/Sergio-Rico/overview|title=Sergio Rico: Overview|publisher=Premier League|accessdate=15 October 2018}} | position = [[Goalkeeper (association football)|Goalkeeper]] | currentclub = [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]]
(on loan from [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]]) | clubnumber = 25 | youthyears1 = 2006–2011 | youthclubs1 = [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] | years1 = 2011–2014 | clubs1 = [[Sevilla Atlético|Sevilla B]] | caps1 = 36 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2014– | clubs2 = [[Sevilla FC|Sevilla]] | caps2 = 114 | goals2 = 0 | years3 = 2018– | clubs3 = → [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] (loan) | caps3 = 18 | goals3 = 0 | nationalyears1 = 2016– | nationalteam1 = [[Spain national football team|Spain]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | club-update = 09:04, 25 February 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 1 June 2016 }} '''Sergio Rico González''' ({{IPA-es|ˈseɾxjo ˈriko ɣonˈθaleθ}};{{efn-ua|In isolation, ''González'' is pronounced {{IPA-es|gonˈθaleθ|}}.}} born 1 September 1993) is a Spanish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for English club [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] on loan from [[Sevilla FC]] as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]]. He began his career at Sevilla, where he twice won the [[UEFA Europa League|Europa League]]. Rico made his senior international debut for [[Spain national football team|Spain]] in 2016, and was chosen for [[UEFA Euro 2016|the year's European Championship]]. ==Club career== Rico was born in [[Seville]], [[Andalusia]]. He played youth football with [[Sevilla FC]], spending several of his first seasons as a senior with [[Sevilla Atlético|the reserves]], in [[Segunda División B]]. On 1 July 2013, he signed a new two-year deal with the club.{{cite news|url=http://sevilla.abc.es/deportes/orgullodenervion/noticias/sevilla-fc/sergio-rico-renueva-contrato-hara-pretemporada-primer-equipo-sevilla.html|title=Sergio Rico renueva dos años y hará la pretemporada con el primer equipo|trans-title=Sergio Rico renews for two years and will make the pre-season with the first team|newspaper=[[ABC (newspaper)|ABC]]|last=Parejo|first=Jaime|language=es|date=1 July 2013|accessdate=15 September 2014}} On 14 September 2014, profiting from the injuries of both [[Beto (footballer, born 1982)|Beto]] and [[Mariano Barbosa]],{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/news/newsid=2141413.html|title=Beto, Barbosa present Sevilla with keeping crisis|publisher=UEFA|date=2 September 2014|accessdate=29 March 2015}} Rico made his first-team – and [[La Liga]] – debut, starting in a 2–0 home win against [[Getafe CF]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/spanish-primera-divisi%C3%B3n/match/402605/sevilla-fc-getafe/report|title=Sevilla FC 2–0 Getafe|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|date=14 September 2014|accessdate=15 September 2014}} He first appeared in the [[UEFA Europa League]] four days later, playing the full 90 minutes in a home success over [[Feyenoord]] for [[2014–15 UEFA Europa League|the same scoreline]].{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2015/matches/round=2000587/match=2014444/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Quick-fire Sevilla catch Feyenoord cold|publisher=UEFA|date=18 September 2014|accessdate=29 March 2015}} In December 2014, Rico was definitely promoted to the main squad, overtaking Barbosa in the pecking order.{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2014/12/03/futbol/equipos/sevilla/1417600813.html|title=Sergio Rico sí se queda|trans-title=Sergio Rico does remain|newspaper=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|last=Quintero|first=Fede|language=es|date=3 December 2014|accessdate=29 March 2015}} He extended his contract with the ''Rojiblancos'' on the 16th, signing until 2017 and being awarded a place with the first team in the following campaign.{{cite news|url=http://futbol.as.com/futbol/2014/12/16/primera/1418761563_417689.html|title=Sergio Rico renueva hasta 2017|trans-title=Sergio Rico renews until 2017|newspaper=[[Diario AS]]|last=López|first=José María|language=es|date=16 December 2014|accessdate=29 March 2015}} He finished [[2014–15 La Liga|the campaign]] with 37 appearances all competitions comprised, including 11 in the Europa League{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2015/05/26/futbol/equipos/sevilla/1432631495.html|title=Consejo de héroes|trans-title=Council of heroes|newspaper=Marca|last=Fernández|first=Alberto|language=es|date=26 May 2015|accessdate=27 May 2015}} which concluded with a 3–2 win over [[FC Dnipro Dnipropetrovsk]] in [[2015 UEFA Europa League Final|the final]].{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3099823/Dnipro-2-3-Sevilla-Carlos-Bacca-scores-twice-La-Liga-survive-scare-retain-Europa-League-crown-earn-Champions-League-spot-dramatic-win-Warsaw.html|title=Dnipro 2–3 Sevilla: Carlos Bacca scores twice as La Liga side survive scare to retain Europa League crown and earn Champions League spot with dramatic win in Warsaw|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|last=Keegan|first=Mike|date=27 May 2015|accessdate=27 May 2015}} In [[2015–16 La Liga|2015–16]], Rico played in Sevilla's [[UEFA Champions League]] [[2015–16 UEFA Champions League|group stage elimination]], but was replaced by fellow youth graduate [[David Soria]] as the team [[2015–16 UEFA Europa League|went on to win]] a third consecutive Europa League title.{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2016/matches/round=2000663/match=2017222/postmatch/report/index.html#sevilla+make+three+liverpools+expense|title=Sevilla make it three in row at Liverpool's expense|publisher=UEFA|date=18 May 2016|accessdate=18 May 2016}} He was still first-choice during [[2017–18 La Liga|2017–18]], but was also involved in altercations with manager [[Vincenzo Montella]] and a group of supporters.{{cite news|url=https://www.elconfidencial.com/deportes/futbol/2018-04-07/sergio-rico-sevilla-montella-aficion-fallos_1545414/|title=Sergio Rico y su insostenible situación en el Sevilla por el pulgar abajo de la afición|trans-title=Sergio Rico and his unsustainable situation at Sevilla for the supporters thumbs down|newspaper=[[El Confidencial]]|last=Sánchez-Flor|first=Ulises|language=es|date=7 April 2018|access-date=9 August 2018}} On 9 August 2018, Rico was loaned to [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] for [[2018–19 Premier League|one season]].{{cite web|url=https://www.sevillafc.es/actualidad/noticias/sergio-rico-se-marcha-cedido-al-fulham-fc|title=Sergio Rico se marcha cedido al Fulham FC|trans-title=Sergio Rico goes out on loan at Fulham FC|publisher=Sevilla FC|language=es|date=9 August 2018|access-date=9 August 2018}} He made his [[Premier League]] debut on 27 October, in a 0–3 home loss against [[AFC Bournemouth]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45924057|title=Fulham 0–3 AFC Bournemouth|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|last=Holland|first=Kris|date=27 October 2018|accessdate=27 October 2018}} ==International career== On 26 May 2015, Rico and Sevilla teammate [[Aleix Vidal]] were the two players called up to the [[Spain national football team|Spanish national team]] for the first time, ahead of a [[Exhibition game|friendly]] with [[Costa Rica national football team|Costa Rica]] and a [[UEFA Euro 2016]] [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying|qualifying match]] against [[Belarus national football team|Belarus]],{{cite web|url=http://www.beinsports.tv/soccer/article/8fmekfgmj7141sxmbdb6mijvl/title/sevilla-duo-sergio-rico-and-aleix-vidal-handed-spain-calls|title=Sevilla duo Sergio Rico and Aleix Vidal handed Spain calls|publisher=[[beIN Sports]]|date=26 May 2015|accessdate=26 May 2015}} but he did not play in either fixture. He was the third-choice goalkeeper for the final tournament behind [[Iker Casillas]] and [[David de Gea]],{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36312769|title=Euro 2016: Diego Costa, Juan Mata & Fernando Torres not in Spain squad|publisher=BBC Sport|date=17 May 2016|accessdate=17 May 2016}} and made his debut on 1 June, [[Substitute (association football)|replacing]] the former for the final 14 minutes of a 6–1 friendly win over [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]] in [[Salzburg]].{{cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/video-spain-6-1-south-korea-highlights-salzburg-friendly-ahead-euro-2016-2376728|title=VIDEO Spain 6–1 South Korea: Highlights from Salzburg friendly ahead of Euro 2016|newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|last=Le Miere|first=Jason|date=1 June 2016|accessdate=1 June 2016}} ==Personal life== In December 2016, Rico was given the Sport award at the Young Andalusia Prizes, receiving his honour from regional president [[Susana Díaz]], a fan of [[Seville derby|city rivals]] [[Real Betis]].{{cite news|url=http://futbol.as.com/futbol/2016/12/21/primera/1482322835_729608.html|title=Susana Díaz: 'No hay bética que premie tanto a los sevillistas'|trans-title=Susana Díaz: 'There's no Betis fan who bestows so much awards on Sevilla players|newspaper=Diario AS|last=López|first=José María|language=es|date=21 December 2016|accessdate=24 December 2016}} ==Career statistics== ===Club=== {{updated|match played 22 February 2019}}{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/sergio-rico-gonzalez/165184/|title=Sergio Rico|publisher=Soccerway|accessdate=13 August
